description: Season 4 of the Netflix show takes viewers into a new decade, with a musical soundtrack to match, including artists like Stevie Nicks, Elton John and David Bowie.
title: How ‘The Crown’ Embraced ’80s Pop
title_page: How ‘The Crown’ Embraced ’80s Pop - The New York Times
maintext:
LONDON — The fourth season of “The Crown” enters a new cultural era: the 1980s. As the plot moves into the Margaret Thatcher years, and a younger generation of royals — including Prince Charles and Diana, Princess of Wales — comes to the forefront of the show, the creator Peter Morgan was eager to take the soundtrack in a new direction, too: pop music from the period. “Naturally, I was over the moon about it,” Sarah Bridge, the music supervisor on the third and fourth seasons, said in a telephone interview. “Stepping into the ’80s was a really exciting time. What an incredible decade of music to choose from.”
After reading the scripts, Bridge started making playlists that reflected the era. The result is a season that juxtaposes an orchestra performance at Royal Albert Hall with Ultravox’s “Vienna” playing from a digital clock radio; the crackle of a vinyl record with the Specials blaring in a packed London pub. Bridge explained the thinking behind some of the season’s most notable musical moments.
Episode 3: Stevie Nicks, “Edge of Seventeen”
